bug.author: AlexanderJLiu
bug.summary: tf-nightly-cpu couldn't trace any graph with subclass models.
bug.description:
System information
Have I written custom code: Yes. OS Platform and Distribution (e.g., Linux Ubuntu 16.04): Win 10. TensorFlow installed from (source or binary): pip intall tf-nightly-cpu. TensorFlow version (use command below): 2.2.0-dev20200426. Python version: 3.7.7 Tensorboard version: 2.3.0a20200412 or 2.1.1
Describe the current behavior I've created a subclass model, and trained it with tensorboard callback. Then I start tensorboard and select Graphs dashboard, but it shows error messages that Graph visualization failed as the picture showsï¼š <denchmark-link:https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/15494997/80565099-3d49f680-8a22-11ea-994d-ddc55ba4ee10.png></denchmark-link>
I've checked the issue <denchmark-link:https://github.com/tensorflow/tensorboard/issues/1961>1961</denchmark-link> here but didn't get any help. By the way, Sequential Model could trace the graph. Describe the expected behavior Things works well when I use tensorflow 2.1.0 with both tensorboard 2.3.0a20200412 and 2.1.1. So I think tf-nightly-cpu should work as well. Standalone code to reproduce the issue import tensorflow as tf from tensorflow import keras from tensorflow.keras import layers import numpy as np
class ThreeLayerMLP(keras.Model): def __init__(self, name=None): super().__init__(name=name) self.dense_1 = layers.Dense(64, activation='relu', name='dense_1') self.dense_2 = layers.Dense(64, activation='relu', name='dense_2') self.pred_layer = layers.Dense(10, name='predictions')
def call(self, inputs): x = self.dense_1(inputs) x = self.dense_2(x) return self.pred_layer(x)
model = ThreeLayerMLP(name='3_layer_mlp')
x_train, y_train = (np.random.random( (60000, 784)), np.random.randint(10, size=(60000, 1))) x_test, y_test = (np.random.random( (10000, 784)), np.random.randint(10, size=(10000, 1)))
model.compile( loss=keras.losses.SparseCategoricalCrossentropy(from_logits=True), optimizer=keras.optimizers.RMSprop())
callback = tf.keras.callbacks.TensorBoard( 'subclass_logs', update_freq=2, ) history = model.fit(x_train, y_train, batch_size=64, epochs=10, callbacks=[callback])

comments.comment: <denchmark-link:https://github.com/AlexanderJLiu>@AlexanderJLiu</denchmark-link> This is very similar to the <denchmark-link:https://github.com/tensorflow/tensorboard/issues/1961>issue</denchmark-link> . Please take a look at it and let me know if it helps.

<denchmark-link:https://github.com/gowthamkpr>@gowthamkpr</denchmark-link> I've read this issue several times. And I've tried some solutions recommended. <denchmark-link:https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/15494997/80668383-590dd500-8ad4-11ea-8b96-a1ca9126291c.png></denchmark-link>
I tried add run_eagerly to compile, and it didn't work. <denchmark-link:https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/15494997/80668516-abe78c80-8ad4-11ea-844a-6291f1abf4a7.png></denchmark-link>
I've also tried customized get_cofing method of subclass model or layers, and it didn't work too. I think this issue is outdated, and couldn't get any useful infomation. The most important things is tf2.1 can trace subclass model's graph, why can't tf-nightly-cpu or the tf2.2 coming soon? Looking forward to your reply. Thanks~
<denchmark-link:https://github.com/AlexanderJLiu>@AlexanderJLiu</denchmark-link> Can you please share a colab notebook reproducing the issue with tensorflow 2.1 and tf-nightly. Thanks!

<denchmark-link:https://github.com/gowthamkpr>@gowthamkpr</denchmark-link>
This <denchmark-link:https://colab.research.google.com/drive/1Uc9trzbx5ObYhUahLf2t6vWGKigsJT45>colab</denchmark-link> is related to tf-nightly. And this <denchmark-link:https://colab.research.google.com/drive/1C3FwT7h1j7qnK1QNoOSOpb355RpFX44F>colab</denchmark-link> is related to tf-2.1. Thanks~

It's seemed that problem still exists according to <denchmark-link:https://colab.research.google.com/drive/12sUyrURdybadYmi-jjayB52LLhWTDcvv?usp=sharing>colab here</denchmark-link> with tf-nightly-2.3.0-dev20200614. Any reply will be greatly appreciated. Thanks~

<denchmark-link:https://github.com/omalleyt12>@omalleyt12</denchmark-link> Alexander here has a Keras subclass model and, of course, it returns for . Can you remind us in what condition Keras constructs a graph? Does all subclass model have no graph at all?

tensorflow/tensorflow/python/keras/utils/layer_utils.py
Lines 133 to 135 in 89df3dd
elif not model._is_graph_network:
# We treat subclassed models as a simple sequence of layers, for logging
# purposes.
I believe this is an indicator that all subclassed models will return is_graph_network as False

Hey <denchmark-link:https://github.com/omalleyt12>@omalleyt12</denchmark-link> , any update on this? As far as I can tell, there's no way to visualize the graph of a Keras model subclass in TF 2.2. Is that correct? cc <denchmark-link:https://github.com/w4nderlust>@w4nderlust</denchmark-link>
<denchmark-link:https://github.com/reedwm>@reedwm</denchmark-link> , do you know what the current state of graph tracing in TensorFlow 2.2 with Keras model subclasses is?

I'm not sure. /CC <denchmark-link:https://github.com/fchollet>@fchollet</denchmark-link> <denchmark-link:https://github.com/manivaradarajan>@manivaradarajan</denchmark-link> can you take a look or triage?
<denchmark-link:https://github.com/manivaradarajan>@manivaradarajan</denchmark-link> any thoughts on this? Seems this is still broken in TF 2.3.
Does this work in the nightlies?

<denchmark-link:https://github.com/tgaddair>@tgaddair</denchmark-link> <denchmark-link:https://github.com/tomerk>@tomerk</denchmark-link> It seems to be working with tf-nightly-2.4.0-dev20200811. Please see this <denchmark-link:https://colab.research.google.com/drive/1ZR3u993vmuLAjm6vMg5OHuw0jRap3Fop?usp=sharing>colab</denchmark-link>
Excellent! I'll go ahead and close this issue then.

Are you satisfied with the resolution of your issue? <denchmark-link:https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSfaP12TRhd9xSxjXZjcZFNXPGk4kc1-qMdv3gc6bEP90vY1ew/viewform?entry.85265664=Yes&entry.2137816233=https://github.com/tensorflow/tensorflow/issues/39008>Yes</denchmark-link>
<denchmark-link:https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSfaP12TRhd9xSxjXZjcZFNXPGk4kc1-qMdv3gc6bEP90vY1ew/viewform?entry.85265664=No&entry.2137816233=https://github.com/tensorflow/tensorflow/issues/39008>No</denchmark-link>
